article: I work just minutes away from one of London's busiest railway stations. Another _ or two away is a lovely, lively street with stalls _ Mexican, Thai and French food, as well as cafes, sandwich places and many other stores. One day, as I was walking around during lunchtime, I33 _ a small elderly lady pushing an empty pushchair slowly along the pavement. I _ wanted to do something for her, but I felt a little _ following around, so I decided to continue my _ . A few minutes later, when I was passing a grocery store , I saw her _ groceries into her pushchair inside the store. That's _ I decided to help by paying for her shopping. The cashier looked at me in _ as I tried to explain that the money I was handing over was for the elderly lady. It must have been the _ time any one had done this in the store, _ she just couldn't quite get her head around the whole thing. And it was _ for me to explain this in front of the other people queuing to pay for their _ . The cashier 45 _ a colleague over and I tried to explain it again. "In a few minutes an _ lady with a pushchair will be coming through the check-out; I have _ your colleague some money that should help to pay for all or most of her shopping." Thankfully, they got the _ an smiled at last.  I didn't _ to watch, but I hoped the surprise awaiting her at the check-out would bring a _ to her face that day.
